data.text: @Brooklywood Yup! You're going to have to really earn that advice now. You'll need to really want it. 😂
@EditrixJen So now I have to be inconvenienced by walking an extra 20 feet to read the latest tantric sex tips?!
@Brooklywood Their very flawed logic is that the sexual nature of Cosmo encourages men to view women as sexual objects and not people and thus encourages harassment and assault. 🤦🏻‍♀️

@EditrixJen I honestly had no idea. Props to Cosmo! But Walmart’s reasoning for moving it is because of #MeToo? I don’t get it. Cosmo is for women. They think men might see it, buy it, and start sexually harassing women?
@Brooklywood (And PS - I buy magazines at the checkout line! I'm a sucker. I will buy any magazine if I'm standing in front of it long enough.)

@Brooklywood Compared to most magazine covers — including Playboy and Penthouse — Cosmo is XXX-rated. No way Penthouse would get away with any of the Cosmo coverlines. We'd have been in hot water for being so brazen!
@EditrixJen Quite an impressive rant! And agreed on all fronts. Let’s be real. Who buys magazines at the checkout counter anyway? Housewives. 😂 P.S. - Is Cosmo really that racy?

@cjlemire They've never been checkout line magazines, but they used to be "front of the store by the register at 7 Eleven" magazines, which was the equivalent, I'd say. But always, always in their plastic bag so you can't read them.

@EditrixJen Pretty sure I’m older than you, and I don’t recall Playboy or Penthouse ever being available in the checkout aisle. You always had to ask for them. From the lady behind the counter. Who probably knew your mom.

@sharon_holbrook I'd like to see equal treatment of men's and women's magazines. Cosmo should be treated the same as Playboy — safe cover only, and bagged so kids can't read it. And I say this as a Cosmo reader.

So if you're going to get mad about Walmart's move, then please get mad at every time Playboy and Penthouse have been pushed out of stores or banned on military bases. Otherwise, kindly rethink your outrage and find something new to complain about. <end rant>
And the other comes free and open and with SEX and other "dirty" words all over the cover and easily readable inside.

This is not to say I support Walmart's move or that I dislike Cosmo. I subscribe to Cosmo. I get it every month and read all the ~1 million recycled sex tips. But I also subscribe to Playboy. And one of them comes encased in plastic and cardboard so no one can see it...

If Penthouse and Playboy didn't feature naked women inside, they would be no more offensive, content-wise, than Cosmo or Maxim or even GQ. Yet we are so afraid of nudity that we will BAN those magazines, yet not see a problem with WORDS that are not appropriate for children.
@EditrixJen Agree that it has little to do with #metoo But it's good news because we don't need little girls reading those messages (how to drive him wild! etc)

So for everyone all riled up because you'll have to walk five more feet in the store to buy Cosmo, think about the fact that YOU CAN STILL BUY COSMO FUCKING EVERYWHERE. This whole thing is a non-issue, and it does not deserve me even having to write this thread. But here we are.

Yet you can walk into any store and buy Cosmo and flip through and read the (very inappropriate for young children) articles. But you can't do that with "adult" magazines. See a problem there? You should.

And magazines like Penthouse and Playboy are sold on newsstands SEALED. They come in clear plastic and you can only see the covers and laws require the covers to be so clean that Cosmo is actually more wildly "pornographic" if you only go by the cover.

And again, they are not banning these magazines. When military PXes banned Penthouse and Playboy, that was insulting and a sort of censorship. And no one got mad because they think those magazines are "dirty" and "bad."

But they moved men's magazines out of most checkout aisles ages ago, silently and without outcry. And Cosmo is as "bad" as Maxim or FHM or whatever else. The only difference is that because Cosmo targets women it gets to be labeled as "empowering" by some women instead.
@EditrixJen That's precisely what I was thinking. They are still selling it, it's just not going to be in the checkout lane.

But also, seeing a magazine in the checkout aisle isn't what was inspiring men to harass and assault women. Cosmo is not contributing to rape culture by showing women scantily clad and discussing sex in frank language. But!

Is their reasoning stupid? Totally. Moving a magazine into the magazine aisle won't magically stop sexual harassment and assault, and claiming they're doing it as part of the #MeToo movement is just insulting to real feminist issues that warrant that label.

So, let's discuss this for a minute. What Walmart is doing is a little silly, yes, but it does not deserve the outrage I'm seeing it getting on feminist Twitter. They are not banning the magazine. They are not saying they won't sell it. They're just moving it.
